bibl.title: Minutes from a conference at the Bureau of Public Health Service, September 27, 1915

div1.p: This conference concerned malaria and ways to combat its spread.

div1.head: Minutes from a conference at the Bureau of Public Health Service, September 27, 1915
div1.p:
In accordance with the request of Mr. Wickliffe Rose,
to which reference was made in memorandum of September 20,
relative to investigations of malaria in cooperation with
the International Health Commission, a conference was held
at the Bureau today at which were present Mr. Wickliffe
Rose, Assistant Surgeon Generals H. R. Carter and J. W.
Kerr and Surgeon R. H. von Ezdorf.

After the reason for the conference was explained by
Dr. Kerr, Mr. Rose outlined the ideas he had in mind in
respect to demonstration work. He stated that while the
matter had not been formally taken up with his Commission
he was considering recommending two lines of experiments
as outlined in the memorandum of September 30th. He made
it clear that the first one of these experiments was to
be carried out under the scientific supervision of Dr.
C. C. Base with the administrative oversight of Dr. W.S.
Leathers, and indicated that the second experiment could
be carried on under the scientific supervision of officers
of the Service, the actual field officers to be trained by
the Service and placed for the time being under the orders
of the Service officers and their salaries paid by the In-
ternational Health Commission. It was understood also that
this Commission would bear necessary expenses for personnel
and quinine. He laid stress on the advantage to his Com-
-2-
mission in having men trained for antimalarial work which
he purposed to take up abroad.

After discussion of the details of a typewritten out-
line of the proposed demonstration which he submitted, it
was concluded that it was desirable to enter into a co-
operative arrangement. It was understood, of course,
that this particular work would be carried on in addition
to the regular Service work. Mr. Rose made it clear that
the studies he had in mind would be confined to farm homes
and not include villages homes or villages. He stated that
the matter would be taken up with the Commission at its
October meeting.
